The ARFrontier was an experimental addition to Heritrix. As such it gave us
certain insights into the general problem and ultimately showed that it was
much more difficult than we had hoped.

Basically, absent accurate change detection the adaptive part is extremely
hard to achieve. As my paper discusses, this is a problem without a viable
solution.

There were also issues with limiting the scope of crawls. Truly incremental
crawls require that the scope be finite (i.e. no crawler traps). Possible
for small crawls, this becomes increasingly difficult as the scope expands. 

The above led me to rethink the whole approach. If we couldn't use adaptive
techniques, then the likely value of a truly incremental crawling style was
greatly diminished. The, much simplified, alternative (which has proven a
great success) is described in this article: 
http://vefsofnun.bok.hi.is/upload/3/ManagingDuplicatesAcrossSequentialCrawls
.pdf

Basically, it is a simple filter to eliminate duplicate documents in a
series of crawls.

This has proven extremely successful and has been used by the national
libraries of Iceland and Denmark (and possibly others I don't know about)
for the last year or so.

See further: http://deduplicator.sourceforge.net

The Internet Archive added a similar ability directly to the crawler as of
version 1.12.0. I haven't tested it myself, but I've heard that it performs
quite well. There are plans at the IA to address the notion of incremental
crawling again but this will not happen until later this year and it is
unclear exactly how that will happen.

The ARFrontier has received no attention of late and currently we are
considering dropping it from the upcoming 2.0.0 release, although this is
still undecided. As far as I know nobody is using it. It seems unlikely that
it will be developed further barring 3rd party contributions to the project.

Hope that answers your questions. 

- Kris
